article.title: Functional Changes in the Snail Statocyst System Elicited by Microgravity
funding: RF President Council for grants to P. Balaban
Fundamental Space Biology Program grant to R. Boyle
article.abstract: The mollusk statocyst is a mechanosensing organ detecting the animal's orientation with respect to gravity.

sections.introduction: Of all the environmental parameters under which a living organism has been exposed in the course of its evolution only gravity has remained constant.
sections.methods: The Foton series of spacecraft uses a modified Soyuz-U launcher and a recoverable satellite.
sections.results: Negative gravitaxis is a behavioral orientation response in the direction opposite to the gravity vector.
sections.discussion: Space flight offers unique opportunities to study how gravity shapes life on Earth.

article.insights_summary: The study investigated the structure and function of the gravi-sensing statocyst receptor in snails following exposure to microgravity. The results showed an upregulation of statocyst function in snails following microgravity exposure, which parallels that observed in vertebrates. This suggests fundamental principles underlie gravi-sensing and the organism's ability to adapt to gravity changes.
